questions.question: Can you describe your First Nation's governance structure and forest management authority?
questions.why: SFI needs to verify you're a First Nation/Indigenous org with decision-making responsibilities for forests in Canada
questions.help_text: Example: We are [Band Name] with a Community Forest Agreement covering 15,000 hectares. Our Lands Department has authority over forest management decisions as delegated by Chief and Council.

questions.question: What is the forest classification and age class of your project area?
questions.why: SFI wants to understand the forest type and stand maturity to assess project approach
questions.help_text: Include: biogeoclimatic zone, dominant tree species, age class range
examples: Coastal Western Hemlock (CWH), 60-100 year old second growth with scattered old-growth legacy trees
Interior Douglas-fir (IDF), young forest 20-40 years with mixed species composition

smart_default.Barkley Sound: Coastal Western Hemlock with cedar component
smart_default.Interior: Check if IDF, ICH, or SBS biogeoclimatic zone

questions.question: Your project covers {project_size} hectares. How could this methodology be scaled to 20,000+ hectares or replicated elsewhere?
questions.why: SFI prioritizes projects relevant for large forest managers - they want to see broader applicability
questions.help_text: Focus on: methodology transferability, cost-effectiveness at scale, other Nations/areas that could use this approach
examples: Our TK + LiDAR protocol for cedar site identification can be applied by any Nation with forest tenure and access to provincial LiDAR data
Approach designed as modular framework - restoration prescriptions can be adapted to different biogeoclimatic zones across coastal BC

questions.question: What specific cultural and socioeconomic benefits will this project provide to your community?
questions.why: ECCC funding requires demonstration of cultural value enhancement - this is a key selection criterion
examples: Enhanced access to traditional medicines (devil's club, cedar bark, berries)
Youth employment and forestry training - minimum 3 positions

questions.question: What measurable climate benefits will this project provide (emissions reduction, carbon storage, or climate adaptation)?
questions.why: Climate benefits are required for ECCC funding - be specific about mechanism
examples: Retention harvest reduces emissions vs. clearcut by avoiding slash burning
Climate-adapted species selection increases forest resilience to warmer, drier future
Structural diversification creates more fire-resilient forest stands

questions.question: Who are the key team members and what relevant experience do they bring?
questions.why: SFI evaluates 'demonstrated knowledge, experience, and expertise'
questions.format: List 2-4 people with: Name, Role, 1-2 sentence background
questions.help_text: Include: RPF/forestry professionals, elders/knowledge keepers, project managers

questions.question: Do you have a methodology to quantify carbon or GHG benefits?
questions.why: Not required, but projects with quantification methods receive priority
examples: Will use BC Ministry TIPSY models to compare carbon storage
Partnering with UBC for carbon assessment using CBM-CFS3
Working with RPF to quantify avoided emissions from reduced slash burning

questions.question: Will this be a 1-year or 2-year project? What are your key milestones?
questions.why: SFI needs timeline - funds must be spent by March 31, 2027

questions.question: Please provide a brief budget breakdown
questions.why: SFI requires budget with milestones. Admin max 10%, staff/travel <40%
questions.help_text: Implementation costs, staff time, training, community engagement

critical.why: Required for all First Nation applications

critical.where_to_find: Community Forest Agreement or tenure documents

project_specific.item: Forest classification and age class data
project_specific.how_to_get: Contact RPF or use BC BEC maps

project_specific.why: Your project is under 20,000ha - need to show broader applicability
SFI requires clear deliverables and costs

strengthen.why: Visual evidence helps reviewers understand context
